title: Strange `inclusionDistance=18446744073709551615` message when resuming validator in some cases
body:
# üêû Bug Report

When resuming a validator sometimes it prints a nonsensical `Previous epoch voting summary` messages with unreal slot indexes and distances.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

I believe this happens when resuming a validator partway through an epoch *after* it would have normally submitted an attestation in the epoch.  When the epoch ends and it prints the usual `Previous epoch voting summary` message, some fields aren't properly set.

The message ends up getting printed as

```
[2020-06-14 03:12:36]  INFO validator: Previous epoch voting summary [...] inclusionDistance=18446744073709551615 inclusionSlot=18446744073709551615 [...]
```

The number 18446744073709551615 happens to be -1 reinterpreted as a unsigned `uint64` which suggests a strict was initialized with temporary "invalid" values or something.

I'm not sure how to reproduce it any more specifically than that, but I did definitely notice it after restarting my validator processes after leaving them off for a few minutes.

Edit: Confirming, I have actually seen them in other places where I had not recently restarted the node, but I'm still not sure how to reproduce that.

## üåç  Your Environment

Debian bullseye/sid using from `87ba5a5993ea835c74c20ca47f930881e0c8a9be`.

Getting the same regularly on all my setups. At the same time the validator balance is reported wrong. This also affects the prometheus metrics.


```

time="2020-06-14 15:38:12" level=info msg="Previous epoch aggregated voting summary" attestationInclusionPercentage="100%" correctlyVotedHeadPercentage="100%" correctlyVotedSourcePercentage="100%" correctlyVotedTargetPercentage="100%" epoch=96 prefix=validator
```

These unreal `inclusionDistance` and `inclusionSlot` meant to be `unknown` because your validators missed to vote on the previous epoch. Go's default is `0` but using `0` would have been confusing. Hence we went with `^uint64(0)`
